segment.source: How to Test Application Publishing
segment.target: How to Test Application Publishing

segment.source: How to Test Application Publishing
segment.target: How to Test Application Publishing

segment.source: How to Test Application Publishing
segment.target: How to Test Application Publishing

segment.source: After your test of first time setup finishes, you can verify that the application publishing functionality is working as expected by performing the following tasks.
segment.target: After your test of first time setup finishes, you can verify that the application publishing functionality is working as expected by performing the following tasks.

segment.source: To test application publishing
segment.target: To test application publishing

segment.source: Verify that the applications that you specified for publishing are visible.
segment.target: Verify that the applications that you specified for publishing are visible.

segment.source: Click Start and then click All Programs and search for the specified applications.
segment.target: Click Start and then click All Programs and search for the specified applications.

segment.source: In some cases, you might have the same application installed two times, one time on the host computer and one time on the guest.
segment.target: In some cases, you might have the same application installed two times, one time on the host computer and one time on the guest.

segment.source: If a published application that has the same name is published to the same location on the host Start menu, it is distinguished from the host application shortcut by adding the virtual machine name to the shortcut name.
segment.target: If a published application that has the same name is published to the same location on the host Start menu, it is distinguished from the host application shortcut by adding the virtual machine name to the shortcut name.

segment.source: For example, for a virtual machine named “MEDVHost1”, a host application might be "Notepad" and a published application might be "Notepad (MEDVHost1)".
segment.target: For example, for a virtual machine named “MEDVHost1”, a host application might be "Notepad" and a published application might be "Notepad (MEDVHost1)".

segment.source: Verify that the applications function as intended.
segment.target: Verify that the applications function as intended.

segment.source: On the host computer, start the applications that you published and verify that they open in Windows XP SP3 on the guest.
segment.target: On the host computer, start the applications that you published and verify that they open in Windows XP SP3 on the guest.

segment.source: The application must appear in a Windows XP-style window on the host computer desktop.
segment.target: The application must appear in a Windows XP-style window on the host computer desktop.

segment.source: If applicable, verify that document redirection functions as intended.
segment.target: If applicable, verify that document redirection functions as intended.

segment.source: If a published application on the guest has to open a folder on the host system drive, ensure that it can open the specified folder.
segment.target: If a published application on the guest has to open a folder on the host system drive, ensure that it can open the specified folder.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Because Windows Virtual PC does not support creating a share from a folder that is already shared, redirection does not occur for any documents that open from a shared folder, such as a My Documents folder that is located on the network.
segment.target: Because Windows Virtual PC does not support creating a share from a folder that is already shared, redirection does not occur for any documents that open from a shared folder, such as a My Documents folder that is located on the network.

segment.source: For more information, see Operations Troubleshooting.
segment.target: For more information, see Operations Troubleshooting.

segment.source: After you have verified that published applications are installed and functioning correctly, you can test whether applications can be added or removed from the MED-V workspace.
segment.target: After you have verified that published applications are installed and functioning correctly, you can test whether applications can be added or removed from the MED-V workspace.

segment.source: To test that an application can be added or removed
segment.target: To test that an application can be added or removed

segment.source: Add or remove an application from the MED-V workspace.
segment.target: Add or remove an application from the MED-V workspace.

segment.source: For information about how to add and remove applications from a MED-V workspace, see Managing Applications Deployed to MED-V Workspaces.
segment.target: For information about how to add and remove applications from a MED-V workspace, see Managing Applications Deployed to MED-V Workspaces.

segment.source: If you added an application, repeat the steps in To Test Application Publishing to verify that the new application functions as intended.
segment.target: If you added an application, repeat the steps in To Test Application Publishing to verify that the new application functions as intended.

segment.source: If you removed an application, click Start and then click All Programs and verify that any applications that you removed are no longer listed.
segment.target: If you removed an application, click Start and then click All Programs and verify that any applications that you removed are no longer listed.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you encounter any problems when verifying your application publication settings, see Operations Troubleshooting.
segment.target: If you encounter any problems when verifying your application publication settings, see Operations Troubleshooting.

segment.source: After you have completed testing application publishing, you can test other MED-V workspace configurations to verify that they function as intended.
segment.target: After you have completed testing application publishing, you can test other MED-V workspace configurations to verify that they function as intended.

segment.source: After you have completed testing your MED-V workspace package and have verified that it is functioning as intended, you can deploy the MED-V workspace to your enterprise.
segment.target: After you have completed testing your MED-V workspace package and have verified that it is functioning as intended, you can deploy the MED-V workspace to your enterprise.

segment.target: Related topics
